ygData.subject: RE: [Re: [Re: Somethin seems wrong (long respons e)]]
ygData.msgSnippet: I ve seen this in other ways, and I have to agree with Nick on the newer people sell at higher prices argument. I think part of it comes from Hey, I can
ygData.messageBody:
I've seen this in other ways, and I have to agree with Nick on the "newer
people sell at higher prices" argument. I think part of it comes from "Hey,
I can make/cast <fill-in>. Lets make some money!". Saw this last night...
14th level Druid comes into East Karana and auctions SOW for 2pp... Heh... I
haven't played a Druid, but I believe they get SOW at 14th, right? I play a
shaman, and we get it at 9th. I've given away 20 times more SOWs (to people
I didn't know, this does NOT include my own party memebers) than I've gotten
paid for... *shrug* And I've never been paid 2pp for a freakin SOW...sheesh.
1pp, quite a number of times, but never more than that. Never. (15th level
now, so I've cast that spell as many times as a 15th level wizard has cast
his lightning bolt...heh).

-Dex Man
Leod, Fennin Ro, Sterling Order of Knights

-----Original Message-----
From: Nick Emmerich [mailto:seorin@...]
Sent: Monday, July 12, 1999 3:29 PM
To: EQ_Blacksmiths@onelist.com
Subject: Re: [Re: [Re: [EQ_Blacksmiths] Somethin seems wrong (long
response)]]


From: Nick Emmerich <seorin@...>

First of all, the RL name thing isn't meant to offend you. People call me
'Nick' all the time,
be it in e-mail, message boards, or whatever. It's my name, I don't really
care. If you do,
however, I'll respect that and stick to Cerran. I'm not out to offend you,
I'm just trying to
prove a point

I'm not especially known for banded on my server, I'm at an equal platform
with everyone else.
If I can sell at a price, other people can too. So, when I sell at higher
prices, that proves
to other smiths that they can as well. Instead of undermining my price and
making less money
per sale, they can go to a different zone and sell for the same price I am.
Sales are out
there, and if the market isn't oversaturated then they always will be. Why
get less money and
contribute to market oversaturation at the same time? Both are negative
things to a smith.
Charging less money, we both lose, charging the same price, we both win. I
don't see how
somebody can justify competition between smiths as 'a good business
strategy'. If they charge
the same price as me, they'll make more money than if they charged less!! I
make more money
since the price raise, it shouldn't be different for anyone else. As for new
smiths who
haven't mastered the trade yet, I have no idea where you're getting your
idea from. Why would
any reasonably intelligent person charge less for an item when they're in a
higher need for
money? This is what you're telling me. Since they need money, they will
charge a lower price.
Usually I put more logic into my arguments, but I can't even touch that
because it simply does
not make sense. Newer smiths would want to charge higher prices so they can
get more money so
they can spend more money on practicing their smithing! I'm assuming that
every new smith on
this board is in favor of the price raise. If you're a new smith and you
aren't in favor of
price raising, frankly, you have your head shoved right up your ass. You're
ruining the market
you're just getting into by selling at lower prices, and you're making less
money now and in
the long run. There is no justification for that, it's just plain idiotic.
-Nick Emmerich
a.k.a. Rennin of E'Ci
Trade Council GM

Peter Wong wrote:

> From: Peter Wong <lkworthpete@...>
>
> Nick,
>
> I appreciate you feeling personal enough to call people by their irl names
so
> I will do the same with you. It is quite evident that you are trying to
lead
> this crusade for price fixing. I would like to inform you that though EQ
is
> not an idealistic economy, nothing is. So as you attempt to fix the
prices
> with the smiths that join you in this endeavor there will be many more
that
> will not. You see not everyone is a master smith yet and they need to
have
> cash flow in order to improve upon this. As you said noone compliments
you
> for being a nice guy or giving them good service, so they'll just go to
the
> guy who is selling armor at a cheap enough cost to make more and improve
their
> abilities. The simple reason being that they don't care if you made it or
> someone else did as long as it works. That's why we will compete with
> ourselves because the money you make does not go in the other smiths'
pockets.
> As long as people continue to join the EQ community there will be people
who
> want to learn to smith. So when they lower their prices to build on their
> skills and move inventory, that is where people will go.
>
> Cerran
